thread.title: Jagler: 'Intense curiosity' drives Microsoft innovations - Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
thread.title_full: Jagler: 'Intense curiosity' drives Microsoft innovations - Milwaukee Journal Sentinel

posts.title: Jagler: 'Intense curiosity' drives Microsoft innovations - Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
posts.text:
Jagler: 'Intense curiosity' drives Microsoft innovations Steve Jagler , Milwaukee Journal Sentinel 3:03 p.m. CST November 19, 2016 Microsoft Corp. President Brad Smith revisited his Wisconsin roots by speaking this week to moderator Mike Gousha and the Journal Sentinel at Marquette University. (Photo: Angela Peterson / Milwaukee Journal Sentinel) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
It wasn’t by plan or design, but three of the top executives in the C-suites at Microsoft Corp. have Wisconsin ties. 
The CEO of the Redmond, Wash.-based technology company is Satya Nadella, who earned his master’s degree in computer science at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. 
Microsoft’s president and chief legal officer, Brad Smith, went to high school in Appleton. 
The company’s vice president of human resources, Kathleen Hogan, grew up in Wauwatosa. 
“We all came in through different portals. But we enjoy talking about our Wisconsin roots,” said Smith, who rekindled his home state connections this past week by speaking at Marquette University. 
Smith spoke to law school students and others in attendance at a presentation of “On The Issues” with Mike Gousha about the keys to the success and the vision of Nadella as Microsoft’s third CEO after Steve Ballmer and founder Bill Gates. 
The three CEOs who have guided Microsoft have one thing in common, Smith said: “The intense pursuit of curiosity.” 
In fact, the “intense pursuit of curiosity” is the driving force behind Microsoft’s innovations as a company, Smith said. 
“He (Nadella) wants to develop not a company of know-it-alls, but a company of learn-it-alls. The key is being nimble. We’re all going to need to keep learning.” 
A sense of “intense curiosity” can be injected into businesses if it is nurtured and promoted by company leaders, Smith said. 
Smith is walking the walk. He is currently three-fourths of the way through reading a biography of Civil War general and former U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant. 
Why? Because Smith was fascinated by the challenges Grant faced as president after the impeachment of former President Andrew Johnson, who took office with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln. Smith wanted to learn how Grant governed a country that was so profoundly divided. 
Sound familiar? 
Although Microsoft is a global company, Smith believes its fate is entwined with the future of the United States. 
Microsoft invests more than $12 billion a year in research and development, he said, and more than 85% of it is done in the United States. 
“We know we have a lot to learn, but we believe this makes one conclusion abundantly clear: In a time of rapid change, we need to innovate to promote inclusive economic growth that helps everyone move forward. This requires a shared responsibility among those in government, across the private sector, and by individuals themselves,” Smith wrote in a post-election blog . 
With advancements in technologies such as the internet of things, cloud computing and 3D printing, Smith said this is a time for America to aim higher and rebuild its infrastructure, including high-speed trains. Such investments are fueling economic growth in China, Smith said. 
The U.S. should leverage its diverse population as an asset, not a liability, Smith said. 
“Over a third of our engineers have come from other countries — 157 countries, in fact. We have employees from every race, ethnic background and religion. If there’s a language spoken on the planet, there’s a good chance that it’s spoken by an employee at Microsoft,” Smith said. “And we’re committed to promoting not just diversity among all the men and women who work here, but the type of inclusive culture that will enable people to do their best work and pursue rewarding careers. We know that this is the only way we’ll fully succeed as a company. And we believe it’s the only way we’ll fully succeed as a country.” 
Steve Jagler is the business editor of the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. Send C-Level ideas to him at steve.jagler@journalsentinel.com. 
Brad Smith 
President and chief legal officer 
Microsoft Corp., Redmond, Wash. 
Expertise: Technology, business, public policy, law 
Previous experience: Attorney at Covington & Burling in Washington, D.C., and London 
Education: Bachelor’s degree, public and international affairs, Princeton University; law degree, Columbia University 
Family: Wife, Kathy; son, Greg; daughter, Julia; dog, Scooter 
Best advice ever received: “Advice growing up from my parents, ‘Take an interest in other people and ask them lots of questions.’” 
Favorite movie: “Thirteen Days” 
Favorite musical act: Bruno Mars 
Favorite book: “John Marshall: Definer of a Nation” by Jean Edward Smith 
Favorite Wisconsin restaurant: Any restaurant at Lambeau Field 
Wisconsin roots: “I’m very much a product of the strong public school system in Wisconsin. As I was growing up, my father worked for Wisconsin Telephone, and I went through the public schools in Beloit, Wauwatosa, Racine and most especially Appleton, where I went to high school (Appleton West). As I spent four years at Princeton, I always felt that my strong public school education was a match for the best schools anywhere else. I’ve always been grateful for that, and I try to give back with support for the Appleton Education Foundation and similar work in Appleton, in particular.” CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE

According to a release, anyone who owns a HoloLens can download HoloMaps for free in the Microsoft Windows Store. Taqtile HoloMaps navigates through a holographic model while simultaneously overlaying real-time data in either a solo or shared experience. The Store Edition integrates Bing 3D to deliver over 200 cities and landmarks as a 3D model of any size with real-time data overlays for current weather and forecast, traffic flow lines and incidents, and geo-tagged tweets. "The list of use cases for HoloMaps is extensive, because the sources of data are endless," said Taqtile Co-Founder Dirck Schou. …
